original_title: Sri Lanka private credit contracts in March, partly driven by rupee gain
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s loans to private and state enterprises from banks contracted in March 2023, while credit to the government continued to expand, official data showed.
Private credit contracted 107 billion rupees to 7,152 billion rupees in March, with the 12-month change going into a negative 5.1 percent.
Loans from offshore banking units fell to 551 billion rupees in March 2023 from 617 billion rupees a month earlier, central bank data showed.
Loans from domestic banking units also fell to 6,601.8 billion rupees from 6,643.4 billion rupees.
Credit to state enterprises fell to 1,593 billion rupees from 1,711 billion rupees.
An appreciation of the rupee contributed to a fall in credit, the central bank said.
The official spot dollar rate appreciated to 327.2 rupees in March 2024 from 364.9 million US dollars in February.
Sri Lanka’s rupee has appreciated amid a contraction in private credit, allowing savings to be appropriated by the central bank as reserves.
Credit to the government went up by 97.2 billion rupees, including from the central bank.
Central Bank credit expanded by 54.2 billion rupees in March but banks continued to deposit excess liquidity in the central bank. (Colombo/May15/2023)
